Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Olefin Polymerization Catalysts with Ligands Featuring Weakly Coordinating Carborane Anions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Vincent Lavallo of the University of California at Riverside is developing new catalysts capable of converting olefin feedstocks into polymers with distinct and desirable properties. Polymers are long chain organic molecules and are found in many facets of everyday life that utilize plastics, including food packaging, structural materials for automotive and aerospace transportation, and lightweight electronic devices. The preparation of useful polymers, such as plastics, requires the utilization of a catalyst to facilitate the chain building process and control the physical properties of the ensuing material. Professor Lavallo is developing catalysts that contain a novel collection of boron and carbon atoms called a carborane anion, which is predicted to bestow unique properties upon the catalysts. Undergraduate and graduate students in the Chemistry Department at the University of California Riverside are being mentored in this program and are participating in the research. Professor Lavallo is also developing a mentorship program for high school students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. In the summer months, these high school students will participate in the proposed research at UCR, and during the academic year, a novel curriculum will be implemented at the high school, allowing a large number of students to directly engage in the project.

In this project, Professor Lavallo is synthesizing and studying phosphine and N-heterocyclic carbene ligands containing icosahedral carborane anion substituents. Icosahedral carborane anions are far more weakly coordinating, less basic, and larger than sulfonates (palladium complexes of phosphine-sulfonates are an unusual family of olefin polymerization catalysts that produce mostly linear polyethylene copolymers), and these properties should favor the formation of the trans-pi-complexes necessary for catalysis and also inhibit beta-elimination. The objective is to produce olefin polymerization catalysts that display enhanced activity, functional group tolerance, and produce polymers with greater uniformity and molecular weight compared to state-of-the-art systems. The broader impacts of the project pertain to the potential uses of phosphine and N-heterocyclic carbene ligands containing icosahedral carborane anion substituents and the planned educational activities targeted towards high school students from economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the funding period we made great progress in the fundamental design of systems capable of making new polymers. Polymers are important materials in all aspects of our life, as they are components of nearly all devices as well as lifesaving materials utilized in medicine. Specifically, we created a new class of catalysts based on boron rich nano-clusters that allow for polymerization to occur and opened up new avenues for future innovations in catalyst and materials design. This work resulted in a number of high impact publications that were disseminated to the chemistry community and general public. In addition, these results were shared with the community via seminars at universities, as well as a local disadvantaged high school. Through interactions with this school we facilitated over 30 summer research internships for high school students at UC Riverside. We have kept track of these students and all of them, primarily from underrepresented and/or socioeconomically disadvantaged groups, have gained admission to universities to pursue STEM (Science Technology Engineering Math) degrees. Through this grant we have also trained numerous undergraduates in chemistry as well as producing seven highly skilled PhDs who are now in the work force as scientists or educators. Overall, the grant was highly successful in generating new knowledge, increasing diversity in the sciences, and the production of talented and highly skilled human capital for the workforce.     

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2020
Modified by: Vincent Lavallo
